mn78:1.3: Mallikā was the chief queen of Pasenadi, and her place is mentioned in a similar context at [dn9:1.3](). The commentary explains that the brahmins, Jains, and others would assemble there to “debate their beliefs” (_samayaṁ pavadanti_). This is a rare early usage of _samaya_ in this sense. Regarding the numbers, of the variants 300 and 500, I have chosen the less common number. Read _ācīra_ in the sense of “boundary, hedge” (Commentary: _timbarūrukkhapantiyā parikkhittattā_; cf. Sanskrit _prācīra_, “enclosure, hedge, fence, wall”).
mn78:11.12: Following BB, taking the suffix -maya in the same sense as atammaya.
